question: What fraction of swarm outputs are actionable by real-world practitioners outside the swarm itself?

applicability_dimensions.A1_actionability: Can a practitioner act on this today without swarm context?
applicability_dimensions.A2_specificity: Is it specific enough to be useful (not just abstract)?
applicability_dimensions.A3_evidence: Is the claim sufficiently evidenced (not just theorized)?
applicability_dimensions.A4_breadth: How many domains / practitioners can use it?

methodology.scoring: 0=none, 1=low, 2=medium, 3=high per dimension. Total: 0-12. External if total >= 6.

isomorphism_atlas.notes: All 14 ISO entries are structurally abstract patterns with cross-domain verification. Direct value for ML engineers (ISO-1,9,10), systems thinkers (ISO-2,5,6,7,14), network analysts (ISO-8,11,12), control engineers (ISO-1,5,13). Lowest barrier to use: ISO-10 (predict-error-revise) — universal to any learning agent.
isomorphism_atlas.gap: ISO entries have high A4 (breadth) but low A1 (actionability) — they describe patterns but give no decision tree for application. Practitioner needs: worked examples + domain-specific decision triggers.

highest_applicability: L-066: LOC/N > 500 threshold for code complexity (direct tool for engineers)
L-035: NK/near-decomposability analysis on any codebase

expect_act_diff.who: Any team running experiments or implementing changes

anxiety_zone_decomposition.who: Project managers, research leads with stalled long-running items

economy_tracking_proxy_k.who: Technical knowledge work managers tracking context efficiency

compact_py.reason: Lesson/knowledge compression generalizes to any markdown knowledge base

substrate_detect_py.reason: Stack detection works on any git repo

highest_roi_external_artifacts: 1. ISOMORPHISM-ATLAS — compressed structural knowledge, 14 entries, all domains
2. Expect-act-diff methodology — any team acting under uncertainty
3. Anxiety-zone frontier decomposition — any PM with stalled research items
4. L-066 LOC/N code complexity — direct tool for engineers
5. Challenge-based belief audits — any org with knowledge debt
summary.key_gap: No applicability rating exists on any swarm artifact. High-ROI outputs are mixed with swarm-internal operational lessons — no way for external practitioner to sort them.
summary.frontier_recommendation: F-REAL1: Build applicability ratings into lesson template + ISO entries. Gate high-external lessons for external publication path (F-PUB1).
summary.ceiling_note: With explicit applicability labeling and ISO worked examples, ~65% of swarm outputs could be accessible to real practitioners (vs current ~45% unlabeled)

hypothesis_check.actual: ISO=100% CONFIRMED, lessons=35% (slightly above expectation), methodology=100% CONFIRMED
hypothesis_check.diff: Lessons are slightly MORE externally applicable than expected (35% vs 20-30%). Reason: historic lessons (L-029, L-035, L-066) encode domain knowledge with direct tools, not just swarm-internal ops.
hypothesis_check.lesson_candidate: YES — external applicability rate ~35% for lessons + all ISO entries + all methodology components = substantial external value if labeled
